pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Antibodies</button> are proteins produced by the body in response to the presence of specific foreign molecules, especially proteins. This reaction to foreign molecules is called “antibody-mediated immunity,” and it is the basis of a technique known as “<button class='glossary-text'>enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay</button>,” or <button class='glossary-text'>ELISA</button>. The purpose of an ELISA is to determine if a particular protein is present in a sample. Besides being used to detect the presence of a protein, an ELISA can also be used to determine the quantity of a protein. In this investigation, you will only determine if a certain protein is present in a sample.

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA)</button> has been used for years to test for viral and bacterial infections in patients' blood by determining whether they have <button class='glossary-text'>antibodies</button> specific to the <button class='glossary-text'>antigens</button> produced by those <button class='glossary-text'>pathogens</button>. Most at-home tests for       COVID-19 are antigen tests rather than ELISA and identify the presence of COVID antigens in saliva or nasal secretions. However, ELISA is a crucial tool in the development of vaccines for the     SARS-CoV-2 virus which causes COVID-19<sup>1</sup>. For a vaccine to be effective, it must provoke an immune response in the patient and cause them to produce antibodies against the infection. After a trial vaccine is given, the patient’s blood can then be tested using ELISA to determine if they have started making antibodies. Because ELISA can be quantitative, meaning you can determine how many antibodies are present in a sample, it can also be used to determine how strong the immune response is and how long the antibodies last after an infection or vaccination.

1Gdoura, M., Ghaloum, F. B., Hamida, M. B., Chamsa, W., Triki, H., & Bahloul, C. (2022). Development of an in-house quantitative Elisa for the evaluation of different covid-19 vaccines in humans. Scientific Reports, 12(1).

pageData.text: The body employs several means to defend itself from <button class='glossary-text'>pathogens</button> (disease-causing microbes). The first component of the body’s defense system comprises the skin and other epithelial tissues, such as mucous membranes. These tissues keep pathogens from entering the body, thus preventing them from causing harm. Should this first layer of defense be breached, either by ingestion of a pathogen or as the result of a wound that enables a pathogen to enter the body, the second layer of defense is encountered.

This second layer of defense is known as the <button class='glossary-text'>non-specific immune response</button>. One of the first reactions of the body to pathogen entry is to increase the temperature at the infection site. Most pathogens have enzymes that function best at normal body temperature; elevated temperatures impair their function and hinder microbial metabolism. Chemicals released from damaged tissue attract certain white blood cells(neutrophils and macrophages) that engulf the microbes in a process called phagocytosis. Should this non-specific response be unable to eliminate the pathogen, a third defensive component known as the <button class='glossary-text'>specific immune response</button> will be activated.

Pathogenic microorganisms have specific proteins on their outer surface called <button class='glossary-text'>antigens</button> (short for “antibody generators”). The body recognizes antigens as not being part of the body and will therefore begin producing specific <button class='glossary-text'>antibodies</button> (also known as immunoglobulins) against these antigens. An antibody is a highly specific protein that typically only recognizes one particular antigen. Antibodies are present in body fluids, and are especially abundant in the non-cellular part of blood minus clotting factors, known as <button class='glossary-text'>serum</button>.

<button class='glossary-text'>Antibodies</button> are large Y-shaped proteins (see Figure 1). The two “arms” of the antibody are capable of binding the specific antigen. The tip of each arm is characterized by a specific protein structure, the <button class='glossary-text'>paratope</button>. The paratope recognizes a unique protein sequence (or <button class='glossary-text'>epitope</button>) in the structure of the antigen and binds to it. This binding will only take place if the paratope is exactly complementary to the epitope in a process analogous to the key/lock principle. In the same way that one key will only fit properly in one lock, so one paratope will recognize and bind to only one epitope. In this way, the pathogen is recognized by the immune system and targeted for elimination.

pageData.text: The principle of the <button class='glossary-text'>specific immune response</button> has been modified for use as a diagnostic tool both in research and in healthcare known as <button class='glossary-text'>Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay</button>, or <button class='glossary-text'>ELISA</button>. There are actually two main types of ELISA: <button class='glossary-text'>direct ELISA</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>indirect ELISA</button>. Direct ELISA tests for the presence of a specific antigen in a patient’s blood <button class='glossary-text'>serum</button>. Indirect ELISA is used to detect a specific antibody in a patient’s blood serum. This investigation simulates the indirect ELISA technique commonly used to detect infection by a number of <button class='glossary-text'>pathogens</button>, such as the human immunodeficiency, West Nile, and influenza viruses; and the bacteria that cause Lyme disease and tuberculosis.

pageData.text: Figure 2 depicts an <button class='glossary-text'>indirect ELISA</button> with a positive test result. In step a, a purified sample of a known antigen is added to the wells of a plastic microtiter plate. This antigen may be purified from the pathogen itself, or produced by genetic engineering. The antigen molecules bind to the bottom of each well. In step b, blood <button class='glossary-text'>serum</button> from the patient (or patients) being tested is added to the wells. If the serum samples contain <button class='glossary-text'>antibodies</button> against the known antigen molecules, then tightly-bound <button class='glossary-text'>antigen-serum antibody complexes</button> will form. Because the antibodies in the patient’s serum bind directly to the <button class='glossary-text'>antigens</button>, they are known as <button class='glossary-text'>primary antibodies</button>. In step c, a <button class='glossary-text'>secondary antibody</button> is added, which binds to the primary antibody. Notice that an enzyme is <button class='glossary-text'>conjugated</button>(attached) to the part of the secondary antibody that is not bound to the primary antibody. In step d, a <button class='glossary-text'>chromogen</button> substrate—a molecule that changes color upon interaction with the enzyme conjugated to the secondary antibody—is added. The enzyme-induced color change will only occur if the patient blood serum contained antibodies against the known antigen introduced at the outset of the <button class='glossary-text'>ELISA</button>. If no color change occurs, this is an indication that either the patient has not been infected by the microbe that was the source of the specific antigen, or that the infection is so recent that the patient has not yet produced a detectable amount of antibody molecules.

When performing an actual <button class='glossary-text'>ELISA</button>, the wells are washed with a buffer solution between each step in order to remove unbound antigen and antibody molecules. In this simulation, the ELISA technique will be used only to detect the presence of “<button class='glossary-text'>antibodies</button>” indicating the occurrence of “infection.” As no quantitative results are needed, there is no need to wash away the excess of sample material. If there is no simulated antibody present, no color change will occur.

pageData.desc: A map describing the procedural workflow of this investigation. To prepare, thaw the frozen materials. When you begin the activity, you will first add simulated antigen to microtiter plate wells. Then, you will add the positive and negative controls to the assigned wells. Next, you will add the patient sample from patients A-F to the assigned wells. Then, you will add the simulated secondary antibody and chromogen to the plate wells. Next, you will incubate the plate for 5-10 minutes at room temperature and observe each well for a color change. If the well changes from green to purple, record a positive result for the well. If the color does not change, record a negative result.

In Activity 1, you will simulate an indirect <button class='glossary-text'>enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA)</button> using simulated patient samples to test for the presence of disease <button class='glossary-text'>antibodies</button>.
Place the microtiter plate on a level surface.

Using a pipette, carefully add 3 drops of simulated antigen to each well in rows A and B of the microtiter plate. Make sure to place the drops in the bottom of the well and consistently on one side of the well. Do not use this pipette for any of the other steps.

For each of the following steps 4–11, make sure to consistently add the drops on the opposite side of the well from the drops of simulated antigen. Refer to Figure 3 to see how the controls and samples should be distributed.
Using a new pipette, add 3 drops of the positive control to wells A1, A2, and A3.
Using a new pipette, add 3 drops of the negative control to wells A4, A5, and A6.
Using a new pipette, add 3 drops of Patient A sample to wells A7, A8, and A9.
Using a new pipette, add 3 drops of Patient B sample to wells A10, A11, and A12.
Using a new pipette, add 3 drops of Patient C sample to wells B1, B2, and B3.
Using a new pipette, add 3 drops of Patient D sample to wells B4, B5, and B6.10
Using a new pipette, add 3 drops of Patient E sample to wells B7, B8, and B9.
Using a new pipette, add 3 drops of Patient F sample to wells B10, B11, and B12.

Take a new pipette, and, without allowing the pipette to touch any of the liquid in the wells, add 3 drops of simulated <button class='glossary-text'>secondary antibody</button> to each well in rows A and B.

Take a new pipette, and without allowing the pipette to touch any of the liquid in the wells, add 3 drops of simulated <button class='glossary-text'>chromogen</button> to each well in rows A and B. All of the wells should contain a light green liquid at this point.

data.title: Antibodies
data.content: Highly specific proteins generated by the immune system that recognize only one particular antigen each

data.title: Antigens
data.content: Molecules on the outer surfaces of cells and disease-causing agents; short for "antibody generators"

data.title: Antigen-serum antibody complexes
data.content: The structures that form when antibodies in a patient blood serum bind to the known antigen in the wells of an indirect ELISA

data.title: Chromogen
data.content: A substance which can be easily converted into a dye or other colored compound

data.title: Direct ELISA
data.content: An ELISA that tests for the presence of a specific antigen in a patient’s blood serum

data.title: Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA)
data.content: A diagnostic tool based on the principle of the specific immune response

data.title: Epitope
data.content: A unique protein sequence in the structure of an antigen to which an antibody can bind

data.title: Indirect ELISA
data.content: An ELISA that tests for a specific antibody in a patient’s blood serum

data.title: Non-specific immune response
data.content: A type of response by the immune system that protects against all antigens and is the first line of defense against pathogens; also called innate immune response

data.title: Paratope
data.content: The specific protein structure at the tip of each arm of an antibody; it recognizes a unique sequence in the structure of an antigen and binds to it

data.title: Primary antibody
data.content: An antibody that specifically binds to the antigen in the wells of an ELISA

data.title: Secondary antibody
data.content: An antibody that specifically binds to the primary antibodies that remain bound to the antigen in the wells of an ELISA

data.title: Specific immune response
data.content: A type of response by the immune system composed of specialized systemic cells and processes that eliminate pathogens; also called acquired immune response

data.title: Serum
data.content: The liquid component of blood which does not contain blood cells or clotting factors
